title: Why is Varus still kicking...??
body:
So I know lore has been iffy lately but a staple of Varus' background is that he's being killed by this blight that he used in efforts to save his home.
And well, I'm pretty sure time is passing and he has been insiting for a while now that he doesn't have much time left... so why is he not dead??

You could argue that time doesn't really pass for the champions considering no one ages in-game but this is lore wise~
And I can agree, this thread was only made for fun but... it is funny to me{{champion:110}} 
(but he's a Heartseeker and we can't let that body die )

replies.body: I don't think death's what Varus has to expect if the Blight finishes its work and overwhelms him, at least not initially. It's much more a corrupting, changing influence, rather than a fatal plague. It's his sense of self, his identity, that he's feeling is on 'borrowed time'.

You asked in your thread about using Gunblade. It's one part of a very experimental test build I've been using. I can say it has worked fairly well early but when team fights start I get singled out massively and the League of CC means I can't use Rift Walk once I'm engaged. Worse, the League of Dashes Better Than Kassadin also kicks in. Getting a bit off topic there... the test build, mock if you want.

Sorc shoes or Boots of Swiftness, Rod of Ages, Abyssal Sceptre, Hextech Gunblade, G's Rageblade, and either Lich Bane or if you can get it, TriForce. It's basically a fighter build with mixed damage mixed with lifesteal and spell vamp. I tend to rush depending on lane opponent. If it's AP then Abyssal, if AD (Zed and co) then Zhonya's is thrown into the mix. Optional for last item is Rab's Deathcap for extra pain bringing but the build's aim was to keep it mixed damage roughly 50/50.

The Pit of Pallas seems to me to be a sentient void creature in the form of this ooze that absorbs and warps all it touches. Changing it into a dark, horrible version of its self. This is why in Varus' league judgement it talked to him, begging him to let it be free and turn the world to hell, showing him visions of people's skin melting off, and oceans of blood littered with bodies (for what does a void creature want but carnage?). When Varus let it go free it changed all the stone in the temple into a black jagged glass before merging with Varus, the ooze absorbing his bow, his arms and legs, stopping only due to the magic of the Wise Owl tattoos (maybe the ooze once knew the Wise Owl? Maybe the owl was what originally imprisoned it there to begin with?). It merged Varus' bow to his arm, becoming a structure that he could absorb into his corruption gauntlets, it absorbed his plate mail on his legs, learning how to become armour in the process. It also likely absorbed some arrows too, learning how to detach parts of its self to fire at Varus' opponents like arrows that rendded their targets to shreds from within. This twisted form of a man and darkness became as such due to Varus' fury at the loss of his family, his pain and his desire for vengeance. Now the being formerly named Varus exists solely to hunt and slay as many Noxians as his arrows of corruption can reach

The funny thing about life and living is that it is rarely so strictly defined in fiction; you, *who* you are, your soul, can die, but if something takes up residence in your body, the physical form can keep living. Varus displays blatant corruption of his form with pallid skin and strange growths on his legs. It may kill him, but plans to keep his body as a consolation prize.

This is my thoughts exactly. I think whatever this blight is, its much more interested in having a physical body to control than some lame soul. The blight spreading is just its way of saying "Hurry up, I'm getting impatient."
Because the Blight is having too much fun killing things. With Varus it has a free ride to an all-you-can-eat buffet of blood, suffering, and death.
